title: Moloko
comment: /* Style */Fixed an inaccuracy. No reference provided.
text:
{{short description|Anglo-Irish electronica/trip-hop duo}} {{about}} {{Use British English|date=November 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Moloko | image = moloko2003.png | image_size = 250 | landscape = yes | caption = Moloko in 2003: Mark Brydon and Róisín Murphy | background = group_or_band | origin = [[Sheffield]], [[England]], United Kingdom | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Alternative dance]] * [[electronica]] * [[dance-pop]] * [[experimental pop]] }} | years_active = 1994–2004 | label = [[The Echo Label]], [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]] | associated_acts = | past_members = [[Róisín Murphy]]
[[Mark Brydon]] }} '''Moloko''' ({{IPAc-en|m|ə|ˈ|l|oʊ|k|oʊ}}) were an Irish-English [[electronic music]] duo formed in Sheffield, England, consisting of vocalist [[Róisín Murphy]] and [[music producer|producer]] [[Mark Brydon]]. Blending elements of [[electronica]] and [[dance music]], they are best known for their UK top 10 singles "[[The Time Is Now (Moloko song)|The Time Is Now]]" (2000) and "[[Familiar Feeling]]" (2003), as well as the 1999 [[Boris Dlugosch]] [[remix]] of "[[Sing It Back]]" which became an international hit. ==History== Murphy had no prior professional singing experience when Moloko was formed,{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/moloko-mn0000487614/biography|website=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=November 17, 2014|title=Moloko Biography|last=Phares|first=Heather|archive-date=9 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160109190601/http://www.allmusic.com/artist/moloko-mn0000487614/biography|url-status=live}} while Brydon had previously worked on music as a producer with musicians such as [[Boy George]] and [[Cabaret Voltaire (band)|Cabaret Voltaire]] on releases from the [[1990s in music|1990s]].{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/mark-brydon-mn0000283364/credits|title=Mark Brydon Credits|access-date=November 17, 2014|website=AllMusic|archive-date=18 July 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160718053224/http://www.allmusic.com/artist/mark-brydon-mn0000283364/credits|url-status=live}} In 1994, the two met at a party in [[Sheffield]], where Murphy approached Brydon with the [[chat-up line]], "Do you like my tight sweater? See how it fits my body!" Its first sentence became their début album's title, recorded while the pair had begun dating. The name Moloko comes from the [[narcotic]]-filled milk drink, Moloko Plus, in the [[Anthony Burgess]] novel ''[[A Clockwork Orange (novel)|A Clockwork Orange]]'',{{Cite web|url=http://www.sortedmagazine.com/archive/magazine/features/moloko.htm|title=Moloko - Greek for Wanker|first1=Donnacha|last1=DeLong|first2=Olivia|last2=Fox|website=Sorted magAZine|access-date=4 April 2016|archive-date=22 December 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161222015118/http://www.sortedmagazine.com/archive/magazine/features/moloko.htm|url-status=live}} based on the [[Russian language|Russian]] for milk, "[[wiktionary:молоко#Russian|молоко]]" ("moloko"). The group signed to [[Echo Records]] and released their single "Where Is the What If the What Is in Why?" The group's debut album ''[[Do You Like My Tight Sweater?]]'' was released in 1995. The group toured with [[Pulp (band)|Pulp]] following the release. The single "Fun for Me" was featured prominently on the ''[[Batman & Robin (film)|Batman & Robin]]'' [[Batman & Robin (soundtrack)|soundtrack]] and received radio airplay and strong [[MTV]] rotation.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/artists/moloko/biography/|title=About Moloko|first=Heather|last=Phares|website=MTV Artists|access-date=4 April 2016|archive-date=14 April 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160414231240/http://www.mtv.com/artists/moloko/biography/|url-status=live}} It reached number four in the [[Dance Club Songs|US Dance]] chart. In 1997, their cover of "[[Are "Friends" Electric?|Are 'Friends' Electric?]]" featured on the [[Gary Numan]] tribute album ''[[Random (album)|Random]]''. After Moloko finished the tour, they built a home studio and recorded their second album, titled ''[[I Am Not a Doctor]]'', which was released in 1998 in the United Kingdom. Though the album was unsuccessful, reaching only number 64 in the [[UK Albums Chart]], a [[Boris Dlugosch]] remix of "[[Sing It Back]]", the third single from the album that originally failed to reach the Top 40 in the [[UK Singles Chart]], was a huge hit, reaching number four in the UK chart and number one in the US Dance Chart. Their third album ''[[Things to Make and Do]]'' was released in the year 2000{{Cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Moloko-Things-To-Make-And-Do/master/74503|title=Moloko – Things To Make And Do|website=Discogs.com|access-date=4 April 2016|archive-date=12 August 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160812201033/https://www.discogs.com/Moloko-Things-To-Make-And-Do/master/74503|url-status=live}} and reached number three in the UK Albums Chart. The first single, "[[The Time Is Now (Moloko song)|The Time Is Now]]" was their biggest hit, charting at number two in the charts. They started touring as a full band along with percussionist Paul Slowly, keyboardist [[Eddie Stevens]], and guitarist Dave Cooke.{{cn|date=May 2022}} Their 2003 album ''[[Statues (album)|Statues]]'' produced two hit singles, "[[Familiar Feeling]]", which reached number ten in the UK, and "[[Forever More (Moloko song)|Forever More]]", which reached number 17. Brydon and Murphy ended their romantic relationship just before they began work on the album and, following a tour, disbanded the group. ==Style== Moloko's music has been described as [[alternative dance]], [[dance-pop]], [[experimental pop]],{{cite web|title=Roisin Murphy|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/rock-ness-artist-roisin-murphy-1-1435740|work=Scotsman|access-date=12 September 2015|archive-date=22 August 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170822094721/http://www.scotsman.com/news/rock-ness-artist-roisin-murphy-1-1435740|url-status=live}} [[dance-punk]]{{cite web|website=abc.net.au|url=http://www.abc.net.au/doublej/programs/the-j-files/moloko/10184704|title=Moloko|date=30 August 2018|access-date=21 July 2019|archive-date=23 July 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210723054317/https://www.abc.net.au/doublej/programs/the-j-files/moloko/10184704|url-status=live}} and [[electropop]].{{cite web|title=Interview|url=http://dujour.com/culture/roisin-murphy-hairless-toys-interview/|work=DuJour|date=11 May 2015|access-date=13 June 2015|archive-date=19 July 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210719185957/https://dujour.com/culture/roisin-murphy-hairless-toys-interview/|url-status=live}} Heather Phares of [[AllMusic]] described the sound of their debut album similar to that of [[Portishead (band)|Portishead]] and [[Massive Attack]] with elements of [[dance music|dance]], [[funk music|funk]], and [[trip hop]], while noting the group had "a sense of humour and sass unique to Moloko." ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== {|class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" border="1" |+ ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:12em;"| Title ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:16em;"| Album details ! scope="col" colspan="10"| Peak chart positions ! scope="col" rowspan="2"| [[List of music recording certifications|Certifications]] |- ! scope="col" style="width:3em;font-size:85%;"|[[UK Albums Chart|UK]]

Martha, VIC, Australia|edition=pdf|page=192}} *"Where Is the What If the What Is in Why?", "Dominoid", "Fun for Me", "Day for Night", "The Flipside", "Pure Pleasure Seeker", "Indigo", "Forever More" and "Cannot Contain This": {{cite web|url=https://i.imgur.com/oyPN1pW.jpg|title=Response from ARIA re: chart inquiry, received 15 July 2015|access-date=17 July 2015|publisher=Imgur.com|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150716153430/http://i.imgur.com/oyPN1pW.jpg|archive-date=16 July 2015}} *''Do You Like My Tight Sweater?'', ''I Am Not a Doctor'' and ''Catalogue'': {{cite web |url=https://i.imgur.com/rYlw97T.jpg |title=Response from ARIA re: chart inquiry, received 17 February 2016 |access-date=17 February 2016 |publisher=Imgur.com |archive-date=24 February 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160224123858/https://i.imgur.com/rYlw97T.jpg |url-status=live }} *All ARIA chart peaks to 29 July 2019: {{cite web|url=https://i.imgur.com/FZsN3d3.jpg|title=Moloko ARIA chart history, received from ARIA on 29 July 2019|publisher=Imgur.com|access-date=25 October 2019|archive-date=16 May 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210516190800/https://i.imgur.com/FZsN3d3.jpg|url-status=live}} N.B. |- ! scope="row" | ''All Back to the Mine'' | *Released: 2 October 2001 *Label: Echo *Formats: CD, cassette | 149 || 144 || 47 || — || — || — |- ! scope="row" | ''[[Catalogue (Moloko album)|Catalogue]]'' | *Released: 17 July 2006 *Label: Echo *Format: CD | 82 || 142 || 7 || 98 || 70 || 65 |- ! scope="row" | ''All Back to the Mine: Vol. I'' | *Released: 11 November 2016 *Label: Echo *Formats: [[Music download|Digital download]] | — || — || — || — || — || — |- ! scope="row" | ''All Back to the Mine: Vol. II'' | *Released: 11 November 2016 *Label: Echo *Formats: Digital download | — || — || — || — || — || — |} ''All Back to the Mine'' (2001) is a collection of 21 remixes (23 in Japan). ''Vol. I'' and ''Vol. II'' (2016) each contain 34 remixes, for a total of 68. Not all of the remixes on the 2001 version are included on the 2016 versions.{{Cite web |url=https://www.discogs.com/artist/1661-Moloko?filter_anv=0&subtype=Compilations&type=Releases |title=Moloko discography at Discogs: Compilations |access-date=4 December 2016 |archive-date=17 July 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210717154424/https://www.discogs.com/artist/1661-Moloko?filter_anv=0&subtype=Compilations&type=Releases |url-status=live }} ===Singles=== {|class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" border="1" |+ ! scope="colw" rowspan="2" style="width:13em;"| Title ! scope="col" rowspan="2"| Year ! scope="col" colspan="10"| Peak chart positions ! scope="col" rowspan="2"| [[List of music recording certifications|Certifications]] ! scope="col" rowspan="2"| Album |- ! scope="col" style="width:3em;font-size:85%;"| [[UK Singles Chart|UK]]

scope="col"| Year ! scope="col"| Video details |- |2004 | '''''[[11,000 Clicks]]''''' *Released: June 2004 *Label: Echo, [[Sanctuary Records|Sanctuary]] *Format: [[DVD]] |} ==Awards and honours== "Best International Live Act" - Belgian [[TMF Awards]] 2004 ==See also== *[[List of number-one dance hits (United States)]] *[[List of artists who reached number one on the US Dance chart]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{discogs artist}} *[http://www.whosampled.com/Moloko Moloko] at [[WhoSampled]] {{Moloko}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Moloko| ]] [[Category:English electronic music duos]] [[Category:English dance music groups]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 1994]] [[Category:Musical groups disestablished in 2003]] [[Category:Musical groups from Sheffield]] [[Category:Trip hop groups]] [[Category:Irish electronic music groups]] [[Category:Irish dance musicians]] [[Category:Irish musical duos]]
